I. BACKGROUND GOVERNMENT AND STRATEGY
A. Damages andMacroeconomicImpact
1. Overall Assessment o f Damages. The tsunami o f December 26, 2004, resulting from an earthquake measuring 9.0 on the Richter scale, off the island o f Sumatra, caused severe damage to coastal areas o f several countries including India, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Indonesia and the Maldives. In India it caused extensive damage in the Union Territory (UT) o f Andaman & Nicobar Islands and along a 2,260 km stretch o f coastline in Andhra Pradesh, Kerala, Tamil Nadu and U T o f Pondicherry. The tidal waves that struck the mainland were 3 to10 meters in height and penetrated from 300 meter to 3 km inland. According to Government reports 10,881 people inIndia lost their lives and 5,792l persons were reportedmissing with 6,913 injured.
2. At the request of the Government o f India (GOI), the Asian Development Bank (ADB), the United Nations (UN) and the World Bank put together a joint team, which undertook an assessment o f the tsunami's socioeconomic and environmental impact in the states o f Andhra Pradesh, Kerala and Tamil Nadu and UT of Pondicherry in February 2005. As advised by the GOI, the joint assessment mission did not include an evaluation o f the impact and losses sustained inthe Andaman and Nicobar Islands.
3. Overall damage and losses2inAndhra Pradesh, Kerala, Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry are estimated at US$1 billion. The largest share occurred in the fisheries (US$568 million) and housing (US$229 million) sectors. Damage to productive assets o f fishing communities inTamil Nadu and Pondicherry were assessed at US$264 million, o f which US$190.8 million were damages to boats and gear and US$73.5 million to infrastructure and services. Tamil Nadu suffered the greatest interm o f damage to housing, which was estimated at US$165 million.
4. An estimated 2.7 million people were affected by the disaster. The majority were from fishing communities (80 percent); the remainder worked in agriculture (15 percent), and small and micro enterprises (5 percent). The impact has accentuated the vulnerability o f coastal communities, and exposed a number o f issues that could affect their recovery, such as the complexities o f implementing the Coastal Regulation Zone (CRZ) Notification3, the absence o f titles as a basis for tenure security, and the continuing decline in fishing industrythat had begun before the tsunami.
5. Macroeconomic Impact. Despite its devastating effect on the coastal areas, the tsunami appears to have had virtually no impact on India's Gross Domestic Product (GDP) or that o f the affected states, which ranged from an estimated 0.15 percent o f the Gross State Domestic

This is mainly because economic activity along the coastline contributes very little to the states' overall economies. A marginal impact on the balance o f payments can be expected in the short term, to the extent that shrimp exports and coastal tourism are adversely affected.
6. The impact on states' public finances i s limited to the expenditure side only. There i s no impact on state revenues because the economic activity along the coastline i s largely in the informal and unorganized sector. The contribution o f the affected coastal regions to revenues such as sales tax, excise, etc. i s relatively insignificant.
7. While the additional expenditure represents a mere 0.02 percent o f the country's GDP, the impact on finances o f the affected states will vary depending on rehabilitation and reconstruction requirements. Tsunami-related expenditures are likely to strain the finances o f Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry due to much larger damages. For Tamil Nadu, it i s estimated that the ratio o f fiscal deficit to GSDP during the reconstruction period (2005/06 - 2007/08) will increase slightly - by 0.2 - 0.7 percent. In the case o f Andhra Pradesh, the rehabilitation expenditure i s only about 0.1 percent o f the state's GDP and well within its overall budget. Total tsunami-related expenditures inPondicherry, over a period o f two to three years, are estimated to be as high as 9 percent o f its GDP. However, it i s difficult to assess the fiscal gap inPondicherry since any financing shortfalls are met by the GOI.
B. Reconstruction Needs and Government Response
8. Immediate Relief Efforts and Government Response. In response to the crisis, governments at all levels have generally acted quickly and effectively. People have been re- housed in temporary shelters, and various forms o f humanitarian relief have been provided. These included a wide range o f relief packages (food, clothing, etc.), shelter provision in 200 relief camps and temporary housing, financial assistance for personal needs, health and psychological services. Additional assistance has also been provided by a number o f other organizations such as UNICEF, non-governmental organizations (NGOs) and the private sector.
9. In the various affected areas, respective Chief Ministers directed Revenue Department officials under the Relief Commissioner to coordinate search, rescue and relief efforts through relevant district collectors with assistance from the police force, fire and rescue services, medical and health services and all other state government departments. The State Relief Commissioners opened control rooms and launched web sites to disseminate information to the public and state officials about relief and rescue operations. In addition, 58 relief camps for 44,207 people were established in Tamil Nadu and 29 camps for 24,978 people in Kerala. The relief camps in Pondicherry and Andhra Pradesh have been closed by n o w as people have left and made their own shelter arrangements. State/UT governments have also provided financial assistance to families o f the deceased, affected families and the injured and announced subsidies for the repair o f housing damages.
10. A t the national level, the Ministry o f Home Affairs (MHA) was designated as the nodal agency for coordinating relief in the affected states and union territories and formed a control room with a help line for the public. The National Crisis Management Group was formed under
3  the chairmanship of the Secretary, Border Management, MHA. Oversight was carried out by the Cabinet Committee of Ministers under the chairmanship o f the Prime Minister. In addition, a National Crisis Management Committee (NCMC) was established under the chairmanship o f the Cabinet Secretary. NCMC's tasks were to draw up ,an emergency plan for relief efforts in the affected areas, and review those efforts together with secretaries o f the relevant ministries/ departments and chiefs o f the armed forces. Teams o f representatives o f various ministries led by a Joint Secretary visited the affected states. Individual ministries also undertook specific efforts.
11. GO1 has also constituted a high level multi-sectoral Core Group for planning and coordinating the post-tsunami reconstruction program in the Planning Commission. Overall responsibility for the co-ordination o f the Tsunami Reconstruction Program will lie with the Office o f the Chief Coordinator (OCC) under the Core Group. A total o f Rs 2,822 crore (US$649 million) o f funds were allocated to the affected states4 and union territories by the GO1 including funds released from the National Calamity Contingency Fund (NCCF). Other funds have also been announced5.
12. The affected states and UT have received corporate donations and relief materials on an unprecedented scale. The United Nations Development Program (UNDP) has estimated that the corporate sector in India may have contributed more than US$8 million in cash donations, food and medicine, emergency relief supplies and other humanitarian services. Indian private businesses and public sector entities have also contributed over US$9 million to the Prime Minister's National ReliefFundand have also provided donations to established reliefNGOs.
13. The total short (1year) and medium term (2-3 years) reconstructionneeds were estimated by the joint assessment mission at US$1.2 billion, the bulk o f which are required for fisheries (US$284 million) and housing (US$489 million).

11. IDARESPONSEAND STRATEGY
A. Rationalefor Bank's Involvementand Link to the CountryAssistance Strategy (CAS)
17. The Bank has broad international and India-specific emergency recovery experience - earthquake reconstruction in Gujarat and Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh cyclone recovery; earthquake reconstruction in Turkey, El Nino flood reconstruction assistance in Argentina, Bolivia, Guyana and Peru, post-flood recovery in Cambodia and China, hurricane recovery assistance in the Dominican Republic and Grenada and other countries. This work has invariably been done in collaboration with other intemational and national agencies as well as non-governmental organizations. The Bank also has a large portfolio inTamil Nadu. Thus, it i s ina uniquepositionto assist GO1and the Governments of Tamil Nadu andPondicherry with the proposed reconstruction program.
18. The Project will contribute to two o f the three pillars o f the Country Assistance Strategy (CAS) of September 15, 2004. First, it will support improvement o f government effectiveness through improved service delivery to the affected coastal communities and their extensive involvement in the implementation o f the Project. Second, it supports the development o f rural livelihoods (the second CAS pillar) by contributing to the recovery o f fisheries, agriculture and animal husbandry infrastructure and identification o f possible alternative livelihood opportunities for the coastal communities. In addition, the Project will contribute to address cross-cutting environmental and natural hazard issues by (a) enhancing the resistance o f shelter and related infrastructure to coastal natural hazards and (b) preparing studies for longer term improvements of hazard risk management and the coastal environment.
B. IDA Strategy
19. At the request o f the GOI, the Bank has agreed to propose financing the Emergency Reconstructionproject mainly through a redeployment o f savings from 15 IDA-financedprojects involving a total o f US$410 million supplemented by a further US$55 million as new IDA resources. This total o f US$465 million would be usedto finance critical reconstructionneeds in Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry, which suffered most severely from effects of the tsunami. In addition, as part o f a wider post-tsunami assistance strategy, several supplementary support efforts are proposed as follows: (a) utilizing proceeds from two ongoing projects in Andhra
6  Pradesh involving US$40 million in IDA financing for essential reconstruction activities in that state; (b) utilizing US$lO million inIDA financing from an ongoing rural water supply project in Kerala to help cover the needs o f affected communities in that state; (c) establishment o f a special tsunami-related trust fund involving grants totaling about US$2.5 million from the Bank's net income for priority policy work in Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry. An ongoing roads project in Tamil Nadu, financed with a Bank loan will partially cover (US$11 million) that state's needs in the sector. It is expected that NGOs will also provide some resources for housing and repair or purchase o f boats in Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry; no estimates o f their contributions are available as yet.
20. Risk mitigation aspects o f the reconstruction strategy will focus on cyclones and floods as well as the tsunami. Therefore, preparation o f this Project was carried out in close consultation with the team preparing the proposed Cyclone Risk Mitigation Project; co- ordination o f effort will continue throughout implementation.
C. Lessons Learned
21. The experience o f previous disaster management operations in India, particularly in the Andhra Pradesh Hazard Mitigation and Emergency Cyclone Recovery Project and the Emergency Earthquake Reconstruction Projects in Maharashtra and Gujarat, has provided several lessons. First, while it i s important to build in hazard risk management systems, these need to be separated from emergency reconstruction activities as they require a much longer implementation schedule. The proposed Project focuses on addressing the more immediate reconstruction needs, while undertaking only background studies that are necessary for developing longer term improvements in coastal management. Second, flexibility in approach, high client ownership and political commitment are essential elements for successful implementation. The GO1/ state government commitment and ownership have been very strong throughout project preparation. Flexibility in project implementation will be ensured through piloting different project activities and through continuous review and adjustment o f the program on the basis o f actual experience.
22. Experience o f the Bank supported emergency operations in other countries underscores the potential risk o f undertaking massive multi-sectoral reconstruction programs involving numerous local and international actors, which can easily strain local capacity. This would be mitigated by focusing on essential elements, piloting where needed before scaling up, and providing built-in flexibility to drop activities that may prove problematic, or shifting resources to more successful components.

27. In-situhousing reconstruction would be pursued to the extent possible. Most housing construction will be carried out by the beneficiaries either through individual effort which i s the case in Pondicherry or through Self-Help Groups (SHGs) as is the case in Tamil Nadu. 28. The Project i s expected to help repair or reconstruct about 140,000 damaged houses in Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry. Provision for resettlement o f an estimated 3,000 families who may be affected by the removal o f encroachment on government owned land for housing the tsunami affected people in Chennai, i s also made in the Project. Project activities may result in additional need for resettlement o f families who were not affected by the tsunami. However, the number of such cases i s expected to be rather small. A clear picture will emerge when the beneficiary surveys are completed and their choices are incorporated in sub-project formulation. Inall cases resettlement will be carried out in accordance with the principles and guidelines o f the agreed Environmental and Social Management Framework (ESMF), and Resettlement Plans will be prepared based on the findings o f the social screening o f sub-projects. B. Community Consultation,PublicCommunication,GrievanceRedress (Attachment4)
39. Intemational experience o f post-disaster reconstruction has shown that no amount o f policy initiatives, financial assistance, and technical know how will be effective without a system to convey their content swiftly and equitably to the affected public, and to hear and assess their suitability and sustainability within communities. In order to facilitate participatory and consultative processes, a two-way communication mechanism needs to be in place. It must convey information from the government to individuals, and also be able to collect and channel community views back to policy-makers. Most important, it must give voice to poor, vulnerable, and marginalized sections. A transparency strategy would enable communities to certify that beneficiaries have been correctly identified, monitor the progress o f work, oversee the inflow and disbursal o f funds and materials, and understand the rationale and process o f policies and decisions, This implies both a ground-level communications network, and a mechanism to integrate ground feedback into policy. In both Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry, representative village level committees will function as the consultative mechanism.
40. The governments of Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry have set up mechanisms to facilitate communication, transparency, and grievance redress. These will be strengthened and made more systematic in order to play a strategic and enhanced role through the duration o f the reconstructionprogram.
41. Village-level monitoring committees will function as the first information node and grievance redress tier. A second-tier will operate at the district or regional level. Full time officers in the project implementing units will oversee communication, transparency and consultative activities, as well as monitor the functioning o f the grievance redress system.

RATIONALE OF THE STRATEGY
1. International experience o f post-disaster reconstructionhas shown that no amount o f policy initiatives, financial assistance, and technical know-how will be effective without a systemto convey content swiftly, clearly and widely to the affected public, and to hear and assess their suitability and sustainability within communities.
2. The government has a leading role to play in collating community requirements, transferring funds and material to the affected areas, sharing knowledge and lessons leamt, setting technical and other parameters, enumerating and sharing location, housing, financial and livelihood options, facilitating civil society interventions, ensuring justice and protection for the vulnerable, preventing leakages, and providing political and administrative support to the reconstructionprocess.
3. Government cannot perform any o f these roles without effective communication between relevant departments, the public and other partners, and without systems for consultation, transparency and redressing grievances.
4. Recognizing this, the governments o f Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry have set up mechanisms to facilitate communication, transparency, and grievance redress. These will be strengthenedand made more systematic in order to play a strategic and enhanced role through the duration o f the reconstruction program.
5. A key feature o f this exercise is that it will build as far as possible on existing community organizations and embedded communication systems, and will involve local civil society and non-government organizations with networks and relationships among the communities.
6. The broadpurposes to be served by this set o f activities are: 0 Dissemination o f information 0 Facilitating community consultation and participation 0 Buildinglocal technical capacity 0 Coordination among partners 0 Transparency to ensure accountability 0 Redressinggrievances 0 Addressingexternal stakeholders and audiences
7. Dissemination of information: This is the most basic and essential communication requirement. Inorder to serve the principles o fjustice and transparency, to share technical knowledge, to retain public morale and faith, and to ensure informed
33  participation, it i s necessary that every single affected family be made aware o f government policies and compensation packages, housing and livelihood options, individual entitlements and rights, eligibility criteria, construction techniques, and grievance redress procedures among other things.
8. Information dissemination i s a continuous process, beginning immediately and running throughout the recovery and reconstruction period. A variety o f media, materials, and methods will need to be employed to bothpro-actively convey information to the affected public, and to make it accessible to those who come seeking it.
9. Community consultation and participation: In order to facilitate participatory and consultative processes, a two-way communication mechanism needs to be in place. It must convey information from the government to individuals, and also be able to collect and channel community views back to policy-makers. Most important, it must give voice to poor, vulnerable, and marginalized sections.
10. This implies both a ground-level communications network, and a mechanism to integrate ground feedback into policy.
11. Building local technical capacity: A big challenge o f the recovery program i s to rebuild thousands o f individual houses to affordable but sound engineering standards. This implies educating, in a very short time and over an elongated geographical area, a large number o f house-owners, laborers, builders and architects, and assessors. The communication challenge includes the very basic one o f demystifying concepts like `hazard resistance', and goes on to the more substantial tasks o f publicizing technical standards and explaining buildingtechniques.
12. The communication strategy must serve these needs at a number o f levels: provide teaching tools and aids to trainers, calibrated for different audiences; function as an information exchange to enable skilled manpower to be judiciously rotated; and, become a force multiplierthrough strategic use o f mass media and other methods to reach messages to remote and semi or illiterate populations.
13. Coordination with partners: Communication between the government and the numerous aid agencies, commercial organizations, NGOs, and community organizations ' which have come forward to partner it in the recovery program, i s o f paramount importance. Not only must their physical activities be coordinated, but it i s imperative that they all follow common technical standards, apply uniform policies, and do not undermine the drive and initiative o f local communities.
14. External partners need to take care not to alienate the local leadership, to ensure participation by poor, vulnerable and marginalized sections, and to be mindful o f the community's dignity. Only a continuous communication interface among the community, the external partner, and the government will ensure this.
34  15. Transparency: A critical element o f the recovery program i s transparency to ensure accountability o f spending, accurate targeting o f beneficiaries, build credibility for the reconstruction program, and retain public faith.
16. A transparency strategy would enable communities to certify that beneficiaries have been correctly identified, monitor the progress o f work, oversee the inflow and disbursal o f funds and materials, and understand the rationale and process o f policies and decisions.
17. Grievance redress: While grievances and complaints are inevitable in a program o f this scale, complexity and scope, what i s important i s the presence o f an independent and accessible system that can speedily resolve them. This system must be credible and acceptable to both the public and government if it i s to be effective.
18. External audiences: It i s important that the government continually engage with secondary stakeholders and extemal audiences, such as the public elsewhere in the state, the media, opinion leaders in the state, the intemational community etc. Messages need to be consistent and clear in order to portray a correct picture o f the situation on the ground, boost public morale, and generate continuous goodwill and support.

doc.abstracts: The Emergency Tsunami Reconstruction Project will support in: a) Tamil Nadu, reconstruction of housing and public buildings, and revival of livelihoods in fisheries, agriculture and animal husbandry; b) Pondicherry, housing reconstruction and revival of livelihoods in fisheries and agriculture, and, (c) both Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry, capacity building in housing reconstruction and coastal zone management, along with technical assistance to implement the program. The first component will have three sub-components: 1) provision of transit shelter, and upgrading of services in temporary shelter sites; 2) repair and reconstruction of existing houses, construction of new houses, and the necessary related services and community infrastructure, such as access roads, internal roads, water supply, latrines, storm drains, electrification, rain water harvesting structures, and limited community infrastructure facilities such as community halls, anganwadi (nursery schools), primary schools, etc.); and, 3) resettlement of affected families. Restoration of livelihoods component, through two sub-components: 1) assistance to fisheries which will include a) restoration of damaged fisheries infrastructure, such as harbors, patrol boats, clearing bar mouth and estuaries to maintain estuarine habitats, and aquaculture infrastructure; and, b) reestablishment of safety-at-sea systems/services; and, assistance to agriculture, horticulture and livestock, to include restoration of damaged agricultural lands, and horticultural lands, farm ponds and dug wells; and, repair/ reconstruction of damaged infrastructure such as veterinary dispensaries and veterinary extension centers, and upgrading of veterinary care services, through training assistance; and, promotion of sustainable management of coastal land and water resources. Components 3, 4, and 5 include the financing of public buildings and public works; technical assistance and training; and, implementation support, respectively.
